newsitem.title: SWITZERLAND: Swiss shares end easier, banks weak.
newsitem.headline: Swiss shares end easier, banks weak.

text.p: 1605 GMT - Swiss shares ended weaker on Monday in a market which favoured industrial shares but were negative toward banks and insurers lower, dealers said.

Banks came under pressure after headlines over the latest twist in a long-standing dispute between Jewish groups and Swiss banks over how much money may have been left in Swiss accounts by Jews murdered in the Holocaust.
Shares in UBS fell 21 Swiss francs to 1,149. CS Group shed 2.75 to 133.75. SBC fell 1.50 to 252.40.
Dealers said the maket worried that U.S. institutional investors could withdraw funds under management by Swiss banks.
"This is one reason for investment funds taking their leave from bank shares," one Zurich trader said.
Dealers said the market lacked power for further gains and many investors worried about a possible setback.
Insurers followed bank shares lower, with Swiss Re losing 17 francs to end at 1,406. Zurich lost 4.50 to finish at 363.50.
Industrial shares were led higher by Alusuisse, up 23 to 1,130. Sulzer, SMH and Swissair rose on the higher dollar.
Trade on Soffex saw rising interest in options on bank shares. Early trade saw bank dealers writing calls. Later when banks shares were lower put options were sold.
Otherwise the market was quiet, dealers said.
127,455 options were traded at a call-put-ratio of 1.66:1. Volatilities were rising.
26,149 SMI options were traded on a call-put ratio of 1:1.13.
In SMI futures, 3756 contracts were traded, mostly around the fair value. The Janaury SMI futures eased 13 points to 3,931.
